sub_topic: Calculation of heat capacity of a substance
message_1: What is the heat capacity of a piece of copper weighing 200 grams when it is heated from 20°C to 50°C, given that the specific heat of copper is 0.385 J/g°C?
message_2:
To find the heat capacity of the piece of copper, we can use the formula:

Q = mcΔT

where Q is the heat capacity, m is the mass of the copper, c is the specific heat of copper, and ΔT is the change in temperature.

Given:
m = 200 g
c = 0.385 J/g°C
ΔT = 50°C - 20°C = 30°C

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

Q = (200 g) × (0.385 J/g°C) × (30°C)

Q = 2310 J

The heat capacity of the piece of copper is 2310 Joules.
